awd_titl_txt: The Sixth Module of the Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES)
awd_abstract_narration:
The 1990s witnessed a dramatic increase in the number of democracies around the world.  The independent watchdog organization Freedom House estimates that as of 2016, nearly two-thirds of the world's countries are electoral democracies, nearly doubling the number of democracies from just two decades earlier.  More recent years have witnessed new challenges to the democracies. The largest movements of refugees since World War II, for example, has put great pressure on new and established democracies alike.  Will this and other pressures decrease popular satisfaction with democracy?  Will it initiate a turn to authoritarian leaders or to populist leaders?  The CSES research project, a collaboration of scholars in more than 60 countries, is designed to be able to address these questions and many more that are equally important to science and society.  CSES collaborators conduct high quality, nationally representative surveys after elections in their countries.  CSES combines these surveys along with additional information about the country and electoral system into a single dataset for use - at no cost - by academics, students, policymakers, journalists, and the public.  At nearly 25 years of service to science and society, CSES has already yielded many important results about electoral democracy and is poised to tackle these and other new questions.

Freedom House estimates that as of 2016, 123 of the world's 195 countries are electoral democracies, approximately double the number of democracies just two decades earlier. The early twenty-first century, however, has witnessed challenges to the success of this great experiment. One of the largest massive movements of refugees in human history, for example, has put great pressure on new and established democracies alike. How much has this pressure been manifested in increasingly authoritarian leaders (even those elected via democratic procedures) and how much has been manifest in the spread of populism are questions that are ideally suited for study through the CSES. CSES advances the understanding of enduring and fundamental questions about electoral choice. The goals of this unique research program are threefold: to illuminate how societal, political, and economic institutional and structural contexts, most especially electoral institutions, shape the beliefs and behaviors of citizens, thereby conditioning the nature and quality of democratic choice as expressed through popular elections; to understand the nature of political and social cleavages and alignments; and to shed light on how citizens, living under diverse political arrangements, evaluate democratic institutions and processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES) is a collaboration of countries from around the world. Top scholars in each country include the same 10- to 15-minute questionnaire in their election surveys. After collecting the surveys, the scholars provide the resulting data and detailed information about their country and electoral systems to CSES. CSES merges and harmonizes these items into a single dataset for use by analysts, journalists, policymakers, non-profits, think tanks, and citizens worldwide. 

The CSES dataset uniquely allows investigation into how electoral system differences impact and shape individuals' beliefs and behaviors across countries, especially regarding voting and turnout. CSES also provides insights into how citizens living under diverse political arrangements evaluate democratic institutions and processes.

The fifth questionnaire of the CSES focused on the theme “Democracy Divided? People, Politicians, and the Politics of Populism.” Freedom House estimates that as of 2016, 123 of the world’s 195 countries are electoral democracies, approximately double the number of democracies just two decades earlier. The early twenty-first century, however, has witnessed challenges to these democratic successes. How much has this pressure been manifested in increasingly authoritarian leaders (even those elected via democratic procedures) and how much has been manifest in the spread of populism are questions that are ideally suited for study through CSES.

Survey data is currently being collected for the sixth questionnaire of the CSES, whose theme is already designed and titled “Representative Democracy Under Pressure.” Thirty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, some have argued that democracy in the world is entering a state of decline. Understanding and explaining this decline in democracy is a challenge the CSES is uniquely poised to take on through its sixth questionnaire.

All CSES datasets are public goods provided at no cost and available for immediately download via the project’s website. The final dataset associated with the fifth CSES questionnaire contains a record number of respondents (114,714), election studies (56), and polities (45). It covers the years 2015-2021 and includes 605 variables. The community of CSES users numbers in the thousands. More than 1,100 scholarly works – journal articles, conference papers, books, and student dissertations – have used CSES data. The products that CSES has made available during this funding cycle will benefit the scientific community well into the future.

The Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES) is a global collaboration of more than 60 countries. Top scholars in each country include the same 10- to 15-minute questionnaire in their election surveys. The questionnaires are developed after input from the CSES user community and are intended to help answer significant questions in social science. After the survey is collected in each country, the local scholars provide the resulting data and information about their country and electoral systems to CSES. CSES then combined all of these items into a single dataset for use by analysts, journalists, policymakers, non-profits, think tanks, and citizens worldwide. CSES datasets are public goods provided at no cost and without embargo via the project’s website.

 

The CSES dataset uniquely allows investigation into how differences in electoral systems impact and shape the beliefs and behaviors of individuals across countries, especially regarding voting and turnout choices. CSES also sheds light on how citizens living under diverse political arrangements evaluate democratic institutions and processes.

 

The fifth questionnaire of the CSES, whose final dataset was recently published on the project website, focused on a theme titled “Democracy Divided? People, Politicians, and the Politics of Populism.” Freedom House estimates that as of 2016, 123 of the world’s 195 countries are electoral democracies, approximately double the number of democracies just two decades earlier. The early twenty-first century, however, has witnessed challenges to the success of this great experiment. One of the largest movements of refugees in human history, for example, has put great pressure on new and established democracies alike. How much has this pressure been manifested in increasingly authoritarian leaders (even those elected via democratic procedures) and how much has been manifest in the spread of populism are questions that are ideally suited for study through CSES.

 

Survey data is currently being collected for the sixth questionnaire of the CSES, whose theme is titled “Representative Democracy Under Pressure.” 2019 marked the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, a moment which signaled the end of the Cold War, and the dawn of an era of democratization in the world. Thirty years on, some have argued that democracy in the world is entering a state of decline. Understanding and explaining this decline in democracy is a challenge the CSES is uniquely poised to take on. Moreover, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic had has important consequences for society, including the quality of democracy, further highlighting the importance of conducting a survey which assesses trends in democracy worldwide.
